div1.p: In going through my desk, your letter of Oct. 1957 — was found & Ive read it with much pleasure.

I'm 74 and find that with age — my memories are very much in evidence. A trip to the Rosebud Reservation when I was 16 — the stage from Valentine to Rosebud (35 mi.) with a stopover at "The Half Way House" — and a stay with the Indian Agent there whose children had attended NNC — as well as several 1/2 breeds whose fathers were government civil service!! Seeing a "beef issue" — that occurred every 15 days — and each Indian had to be indentified — how amusing it was to hear the interpreter call out "Mrs. Spotted Tail #2" etc. etc.!!

And, John, did you know about the wonderful Indian discoveries in the 1930—1936 - at St. James, Nebraska? Professor Bell, of Nebraska Uni. wrote
it up and when Fred & I took mothers ashes to Wayne in 1937 — we went to see that and the farmer (his wife was a former student) let us prowl around & the artifacts & reconstruction was so very interesting.

When I read so much these days about bigotry etc. & I never heard the word Jew or felt any difference in way the Indians who attended our school were so different! And father had cooks make a second Sunday breakfast for Catholics who went downtown to early mass!
All that rushes thru my mind and I think its a fine occupation for an old lady to have memories that keep her from feeling lonely.

My lovely grandaughter (17) is in college at Iowa Wesleyan in Mt. Pleasant, Iowa — her folks were there on Parent Day (Oct. 8) and she is happy & becoming adjusted. My son is
3 23
7912 North Karlov Avenue
Skokie 6, Illinois
with Standard Oil of Indiana — in Employee Relations — head of division of Job Analysis — and his offices are in their Executive Bldg in Chgo.
This village is 2 1/2 miles from Evanston, 14 miles from center of Chicago — & has grown from 14,000 when I came here 11 years ago to over 58,000 now. Excellent schools & quiet environment.
Please give my affectionate regard to Mrs. Mona & to you — best of all good wishes — from
div1.closer:
Helen Pile Newton
Mrs. George Reid Newton

postscript.p: P.S. I wish I were near enough for you to read two very interesting books of Connecticut History — One is "Documetary History of Suffield in the Colony & Province of the Massachusetts Bay, in New England 1660-1749 only 250 copies printed and contains town records etc — & is the most complete record of early settlers I've ever read.
The second is a pamphlet Title is "Suffield and the Lexington Alarm" in April 1775

Suffield Conn. is a town midway beterrn Hartford Conn & Springfield, Mass — and my husband was born there & all the family heirlooms came to him as last male of family & now son Richard is last of the line so we have so many things of Colonial times. Your Mona would enjoy seeing a large oil Portrait painted in 1837 of "Uncle Joel" Newton — a chaplain in the Navy. You know John, I've never know much 'old' history as far as Nebraska was concerned & to be "dumped" into all that was a bit startling at first. I'm closing & excuse my rambling — affectionately, Helen
